```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```


```{r setup q1}
rm(list = ls()) # removes all variables
if(!is.null(dev.list())) dev.off() # clear plots
cat("\014") # clear console

# import required packages
library(caret, warn.conflicts = F, quietly = T)
library(dplyr)
library(reshape2)
library(alookr)

set.seed(123) # sets seed for repeat ability of randomly generated numbers

file <- 'http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/breast-cancer-wisconsin/wdbc.data' # store the path to the source data
rawData <- read.csv(file, header = FALSE, stringsAsFactors = TRUE) # import source data, in this case the data file has no headers and strings will be used a factors
names(rawData) <- c("id", "diagnosis", "radius_mean", "texture_mean","perimeter_mean", "area_mean", "smoothness_mean", "compactness_mean", "concavity_mean", "concave.points_mean", "symmetry_mean",  "fractal_dimension_mean", "radius_se", "texture_se","perimeter_se", "area_se", "smoothness_se", "compactness_se", "concavity_se", "concave.points_se", "symmetry_se", "fractal_dimension_se", "radius_worst", "texture_worst","perimeter_worst", "area_worst", "smoothness_worst", "compactness_worst", "concavity_worst", "concave.points_worst", "symmetry_worst", "fractal_dimension_worst")

```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r clean data}

modelData <- cleanse()

```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
